Award.AwardTitle: GSE/RES Collaborative Research: Addressing the STEM Gender Gap: Does Spatial Training Enhance Middle-School Girls' STEM-Relevant Spatial Skills, Attitudes, Beliefs, and Interests?

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Intellectual Merit: Michigan Technological University and Pennsylvania State University propose a collaborative project to test the hypothesis that an educational intervention (earlier shown to increase retention of woman engineering students) may also increase middle-school girls' STEM-relevant spatial skills. The project will further test the hypothesis that increases in cognitive spatial skill will also enhance girls' self-efficacy and valuing of spatial skills, and decrease the stereotyping of such skills as masculine. The intervention effects on STEM-related course choices and job interests will also be examined, while testing whether effects of the spatial-skill intervention, if observed, are (a) the direct result of enhanced spatial skills or (b) mediated by girls' changed self-efficacy, values, and stereotypes. Approximately 400 7th grade students in two diverse middle schools will be randomly assigned, by classrooms, to receive the spatial skills curriculum or to receive their regular instruction. Prior to and following the intervention, and again approximately a year later, all students will complete an assessment battery to measure their spatial skills and attitudes and beliefs about spatial skills (self-confidence/efficacy, values, stereotyping). At the end of 8th grade, all students will be assessed for their interests in and plans for spatially-demanding STEM courses and careers.

Broader Impacts: The project PIs and Co-PIs will provide training on the curriculum to middle-school teachers in the two cooperating school districts, monitor student success and the fidelity of implementation. Dissemination efforts will reflect the interdisciplinary nature of the team (collaborative PIs and Co-PIs represent the fields of engineering, developmental and cognitive science, and gender studies), the relevance of spatial thinking for a wide array of science and engineering organizations, and the simultaneous theoretical and educational goals of the study.

ProgramElement.Text: RES ON GENDER IN SCI & ENGINE

POR.DRECONTENT:
A national goal is to provide educational experiences that will increase citizens' participation and success in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM). This goal is especially important for girls and women who remain underrepresented in STEM fields. Because there is strong evidence that spatial skills are linked to STEM success, and because many girls and women have not developed strong spatial skills, this project tested whether giving middle-school students a spatial skills curriculum would enhance the spatial skills, STEM interests, and achievements of students—especially girls.

The project involved about 400 students enrolled in 7th grade (G7) classrooms in two US school districts, one in the West (about 70% Latino/a; about 75% qualifying for free lunch) and the other in the Midwest (about 95% White; about 30% qualifying for free lunch). In two consecutive years, some teachers ("experimental") included a spatial skills curriculum as part of their G7 math classes whereas other teachers ("control") followed the usual math curriculum. Immediately before the curriculum units (G7 pretest), immediately after (G7 posttest), and another year later (G8), all students were tested on their spatial skills and asked about their beliefs and interests in STEM and other activities and jobs. Another year later (G9) children were asked about their interests in various courses and clubs.  Throughout the years of the project, students' STEM achievement was monitored using their grades in science and math classes and their scores on state-level science and math achievement tests.

There was evidence that on spatial tests, students who had received the spatial curriculum gained more over time than did students in the control classrooms, but the advantage was modest and inconsistent across samples. Results from measures of STEM achievement (class grades and state-achievement test scores) revealed no differences between students in experimental versus control classes.  Data from the various measures of student interests and personal identities (e.g., job and club interests, self-reported self-confidence in spatial skills or STEM fields) showed expected (traditional) gender differences but, again, no evidence of a curriculum effect. Ongoing analyses are examining connections among spatial skills, STEM achievement, and social-cognitive factors (e.g., self-confidence) within individual children.  Taken together, the findings from this project suggest that a teacher-implemented spatial skills curriculum embedded within an ongoing mathematics course can have some positive effects on middle-school students' spatial skills, but that to see larger, more consistent, and more general academic effects (e.g., improved science and math mastery) is likely to need more intense and sustained instruction and/or explicit classroom attention to ways that spatial skills are relevant to STEM challenges, coursework, and careers.
